Award.AwardTitle: SaTC: EDU: Collaborative: Curriculum to Broaden Participation in Cybersecurity for Middle School Teachers and Students (CyberMiSTS)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Curriculum to Broaden Participation in Cybersecurity for Middle School Teachers and Students (CyberMiSTS) project will develop and pilot summer workshops that provide middle school Career and Technical Education (CTE) teachers with the knowledge, skills, and tools they need to actively engage their students and expose them to cybersecurity concepts and careers. Bringing in cybersecurity expertise from a variety of sources, the CyberMiSTS curriculum will be accessible to middle school students and teachers because it will emphasize the important role of humans in cybersecurity. Teachers will learn from cybersecurity researchers, engage in hands-on activities, and customize cybersecurity course materials for their own classrooms. The CyberMiSTS curriculum will focus on key concepts and big questions to encourage participation from a broad and diverse set of students.

Using a design research methodology to develop the training approach, with teachers from the first cohort sharing their experiences and mentoring a second cohort, the project team will study what CTE teachers need to be successful teaching cybersecurity in a middle school classroom. The project builds on lessons learned from a previous SaTC EDU project by incorporating Comic-BEE, a novel online system for creating educational, branching web comics. Branching stories provide opportunities to explore cause and effect. The comic style is engaging to middle school students who are disinclined to read long texts, and can incorporate culturally relevant pedagogy with the potential to reach more students. After the summer workshop, teachers will the materials in their classrooms, and measure student learning and interest in cybersecurity careers with instruments provided by the project team. In the future, workshop materials and curriculum will be offered as an online continuing education course.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
To broaden and increase participation in the relatively new and rapidly growing field of cybersecurity, we need to attract more students.  Research shows that to do this, students need to be engaged with cybersecurity during middle school. There is, however, a lack of age appropriate and classroom-ready cybersecurity curriculum, and many teachers feel unprepared to teach the subject. As a result, very few middle school teachers introduce their students to cybersecurity, which leads to significant lost opportunities to grow the pipeline of future workers in this field that, as shown by the December 2020 SolarWinds hack, is critical to our both the national security and economic competitiveness of the United States.

Secure Decisions collaborated with Stony Brook University on The Curriculum to Broaden Participation in Cybersecurity for Middle School Teachers and Students (CyberMiSTS) project. This two-year effort identified what preparation and materials middle school teachers need to be successful in introducing cybersecurity to students in class. Summer workshops provided two cohorts of teacher participants the knowledge, skills, and tools to actively engage all their students and expose them to cybersecurity concepts and careers. Rather than diving deeply into the underlying math and science, or requiring a computer lab in the classroom, the CyberMiSTS summer workshop focused on key concepts (Data Protection, Web Security and Privacy) and big questions (What information should be protected? How can online information be protected? What can I do to protect my information?) that could be addressed by any teacher, in any classroom. The workshop was designed to help teachers show students how poor cybersecurity directly impacts everyone, not just adults.

No prior cybersecurity or computer science experience was required. We encouraged participation from a broad and diverse set of teachers of subjects including computer science, math, science, technology, business, research and English. The project seeks to increase not just racial or gender diversity, but also attitude diversity: cybersecurity needs more students who are deeply interested in people and society, rather than computers and technology.

The workshop curriculum we developed includes lectures from experts and open-source hands-on classroom activities for middle-school students that do not require coding, a computer lab or software to be installed. A former cybersecurity practitioner shared information about cybersecurity careers to help dispel the myths that you must write code or have advanced degrees to get a cybersecurity job. In the second half of the workshop, teachers created classroom curriculum for their cybersecurity units. As a capstone exercise, each teacher used the Comic-BEE.com web application to create a branching web comic --where readers make choices for a character and see the consequences of those choices-- that illustrated a cybersecurity lesson relevant to their students.

Data collected revealed teacher confidence about key cybersecurity concepts both before and after each summer workshop. Teachers in both cohorts gained knowledge and reported strong increases in their self-efficacy on cybersecurity fundamentals, as well as topics related to Data Protection, Web Security  and cybersecurity careers. At the end of each workshop, teachers were excited about the prospect of bringing their curriculum to their students.

Teachers who used their cybersecurity curriculum in the classroom also shared anonymous and aggregated student data with us, helping identify classroom approaches that are effective in sparking interest in cybersecurity. In one class, after researching cybersecurity work roles, nearly 15% of responses by students indicated that the student would consider pursuing specific cybersecurity work roles.

The two primary researchers on this collaborative project and daily leads of the teacher workshop were women, including the cybersecurity practitioner subject matter expert. The project's graduate researcher further developed her understanding of cybersecurity, and half of the workshop participants were women. The 2020 workshop in particular improved the performance, skills and attitudes of teachers of special ed students, who are an underrepresented group in science, technology and cybersecurity. Particularly through the NSF STEMForALL VideoHall events (https://multiplex.videohall.com/), the CyberMiSTS project provided exposure to both cybersecurity, science and technology concepts and careers to a broader group of teachers and educators, and the young people served by those educators.

The CyberMiSTS project has identified an initial, evidence-based approach for teacher professional development that enables middle school teachers to rapidly develop familiarity and confidence with foundational cybersecurity curriculum. This approach may also be applicable to other professional development efforts where educators are being asked to quickly come up to speed so that they can teach the new subject to their own students. Teachers that incorporate their CyberMiSTS curriculum into their specific classroom subjects have successfully infused cybersecurity across the K12 curriculum.
